General course objectives:
General course objectives
The course aims at introducing the student to the fundamentals of nuclear reactor physics and nuclear power generation. The course provides the theoretical foundation for understanding nuclear reactor dynamics and control and includes Monte Carlo simulation of a simplified reactor model. We discuss current and the next generation of nuclear power reactors.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Describe the nuclear liquid drop and nuclear shell models
Explain nuclear energetics and nuclear binding energies
Describe neutron interactions and the fission process
Explain neutron life cycles in fission reactors
Analyze basic fission reactor principles and design
Account for the six-factor formula and the role of delayed neutrons
Account for reactivity feedback mechanisms
Analyze the effect of neutron poisons on reactor dynamics
Apply Monte Carlo techniques to reactor steady state and transients
Account for Generation III and IV nuclear power reactors
Content: Nuclear models, energetics and reactions, radioactivity, radiation transport and interactions, principles of nuclear reactors, reactor dynamics and control, reactor physics calculations, nuclear power reactors, Monte Carlo simulation of a simplified reactor model.
Course literature: Fundamentals of Nuclear Science and Engineering (J. Kenneth Shultis and Richard E. Faw, 2007: Ch. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11) samt noter om neutrontransportteori.
